Increasing interest in tetrazoles and tetrazole based materials in the recent century has been followed by enormous research efforts devoted for the synthesis of various kinds of materials based on these five membered heterocyclic compounds, which basically contain four nitrogen atoms. The structure of tetrazoles and their derivatives are crucial in preparing complexes since they can act as ligands to modify the reactivity and selectivity of the metal centers in the catalyst and prepare energetic materials. The wide field of tetrazole applications as efficient, air stable and inexpensive materials has drawn attention to the methods to synthesize various kinds of tetrazoles and their derivatives. This study primarily focuses on the fabrication methods of tetrazoles and preparation of tetrazole based compounds and their utilizations in environmental, catalytic, and energetic applications. The significant applications of tetrazole, as a catalyst, energetic material and efficient ligand in the organic catalysis or formation of various catalysts are described with an emphasis on its performance, reusability and stability and environmental concerns such as treatment of wastewater and water. Finally, a brief summary and an outlook on some of the scientific challenges and opportunities of these materials have also been discussed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keyword Tetrazole (Nano)catalyst Chemical transformations Environmental Energetic 1 Introduction Tetrazoles, a multi-purpose group of five membered N-containing heterocyclic compounds containing four nitrogens and a carbon and exist in two 1H- and 2H- tautomeric forms, which the 1H- form is more stable and predominant in solution phase, while form of 2H- is more stable in the gas phase (Fig. 1 ) [1-17]. Tetrazoles possess excellent properties such as low basicity, high acidity, large number of nitrogen, high stability and formation enthalpy; have been used as analytical reagents in the material science [2-5], as lipophilic spacers in medicinal chemistry [6,7], antihypertensive drugs [8], efficient antitumor and anticancer agents [9-11], peptidase inhibitors [12], starting materials for the synthesis of propellants [13], energetic materials [14], and N-containing compounds [15] and principally ligands for the organization of complexes [16,17]. Tetrazoles exhibit potential biological activity due to their application as a metabolically stable surrogate (bioisostere) for -COOH group (Fig. 2 ). However, the tetrazole moiety is metabolically more stable than the carboxylic acid group, which make it a suitable substitution in drug design (Fig. 3 ) [18]. Due to their immense suitability, the fundamental study on the preparation of tetrazoles and their applications has attracted great interest. Recently, chemists have become increasingly focused on the preparation of various tetrazoles using heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. However, complications in recovering the catalysts have restricted their wide application in industry. Thus, choosing a suitable catalyst to prepare these ligands is of paramount importance to attain good results [18-20]. Catalysts are essential as they are practical in most industrial procedures wherein they help to increase the rate of reactions and perform selectively to produce only one product, accordingly avoiding side products or waste generation, resulting in more efficient, environmentally benign and atom-economical procedures. The use of homogeneous catalysis represents one of the most efficient and important methods for conducting chemical transformations in which the catalyst often contains a transition metal surrounded by ligands [21-26]. Recently, the concept of metal-ligand cooperation has gathered a lot of interest and is currently a rapidly expanding field of homogeneous catalysis [27-42]. Over the past decades, there has been a renaissance in metal catalyzed organic reactions using phosphine ligands [43,44]. However, there are many drawbacks in the deployment of phosphine ligands as catalysts; namely, low activities, catalyst decomposition, poor solubility and sensitivity to moisture and air oxidation. The attainment of selectivity in chemical processes inevitably requires modifying ligands on the transition metal center [45-52]. The replacement of the often used phosphines with tetrazole type ligands has given rise to highly active systems in metal catalyzed organic reactions. Various tetrazoles have extensive applications in homogeneous catalysis; especially in medicinal and coordination chemistry. Apparently, the number of publications on new catalysts containing the tetrazole moieties has increased annually [53,54]. In view of the unique structural properties and air stability, tetrazoles play a prominent role in heterogeneous catalysis, which is strategically vital in eco-friendly organic transformations with upsurge indispensability for industrial applications. There are numerous reports about tetrazole coordination with transition metals for the preparation of the corresponding chelate complexes with palladium, copper, iridium, etc. as well as their application in fine chemicals, explosives and pharmaceuticals [55-58]. However, the lack of an appropriate review for the organization of tetrazole based catalysts strongly curbs their importance in the chemistry for research scientists. This review primarily focuses on the preparation of catalysts derived from these ligands and their catalytic applications. These ligands modify the reactivity and selectivity of the metal centers in catalysis [59,60]. This effort also focuses on the various applications of these complexes, particularly in catalysis and their future prospective applications in chemistry. This review largely provides multiple perspectives pertaining to the current challenges encountered in the catalyst design and preparation, by displaying the progresses attained so far in expanding heterogeneous catalysts and their reusability in continuous processes. We expect this appraisal to be useful for researchers in the field of catalysis, nanoscience and nanotechnology, organic transformations, green synthesis for research centers and industries alike. Tetrazole assisted catalysis of organic reactions and chemical transformations has been recognized in the literature due to the remarkable functions of tetrazole in diverse fields of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. In view of the difficulties in recovering homogeneous catalysts [61,62], efficient, simple, and convenient routes to synthesize these tetrazole based heterogeneous catalysts need to be explored. Over the last few decades, these catalysts have been considered strategically vital in several eco-friendly organic transformations with respect to their properties such as low toxicity, high stability and catalytic prowess [21,29]. Additionally, transforming tetrazoles into valuable heterogeneous catalysts tremendously enhances the sustainable economic development as exemplified by the growing demand for the nanomaterials and (nano)catalysts using tetrazole [30,32,33]. Hence, the synthesis of nanomaterials and (nano)catalysts utilizing these materials presents an enormous opportunity for addressing the future catalytic demands. The supply of clean and healthy drinking water is becoming increasingly challenging throughout the world [63-69]. Many heterocycles containing embedded tetrazole cores have been used for environmental applications via the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts deploying various supports such as magnetic Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles, polymers, and other natural materials, a recent example being the heterogeneous polymer supported metal complexes exploiting azole type ligands such as tetrazole. Tetrazole based (nano)materials have been developed and applied as effective adsorbents or catalysts for wastewater treatment and purification. Despite impressive gains in this field, the design of suitable tetrazole ligands for a particular application remains a formidable task. In this review, current trends and future prospects exploiting the application of sustainable tetrazole based (nano)materials for water and wastewater treatments are discussed [70-72]. In addition, another part of the review focuses on the application of tetrazoles as energetic materials [73,74]. This review aims at providing a concise introduction to the energetic applications of materials based on tetrazoles. Studies on these topics are still in the state of infancy and it is imperative to provide a review for scientists interested in this emerging research area as well as the design of (nano)catalysts and environmental and energetic applications. Therefore, this unique review may fill up the gap in this area. 2 Synthesis of various tetrazoles Generally, according to the substituent number, tetrazoles are divided into three categories including parent, monosubstituted and disubstituted tetrazoles (Fig. 4 ). Tetrazoles (Fig. 5 ) are conventionally produced via the reaction of dangerous and harmful azide ions or hydrazoic acid with various nitriles, cyanamides or thiocyanates using homogeneous catalysts. Earlier approaches for the synthesis of tetrazoles were associated with drawbacks such as the utilization of toxic, moisture sensitive and expensive reagents and stoichiometric quantities of homogeneous catalysts, environmental contamination caused by production of by-products and heavy metal waste, low yields or hard procedures for the preparation of the starting materials or catalysts and difficult work-up procedures [18,75]. The as-mentioned drawbacks have limited the industrial large scale application of tetrazoles. Later, tetrazoles were mainly prepared from the condensation of nitriles or thiocyanates with sodium azide (NaN3) and NH4Cl or other proton sources such as triethylamine hydrochloride, butyldimethyl hydrochloride, butyldiethylamine hydrochloride, tributylamine hydrochloride, trioctylamine hydrochloride and tripropylamine hydrochloride as proton sources and an alternative for HN3. However, combining NaN3 with NH4Cl as an acid may produce gaseous HN3, which is potentially hazardous. Recently, different attempts have been focused on the improvement of new and green routes to decrease or remove the utilization and production of dangerous compounds [75,76]. Herein, the common methods for the synthesis of known tetrazoles are presented. 2.1 5-Substituted tetrazoles 5-Substituted tetrazoles are useful in medicinal, coordination and organic chemistry, explosives and photography [18,76]. In organic chemistry, this derivative of tetrazole is an advantageous intermediate in organic synthesis. Scheme 1 represents some routes to synthesize these kinds of tetrazole derivatives. The principle of most of these methods is the condensation of a CN group and an azide moiety. 5-Substituted tetrazoles can be synthesized by (i) microwave assisted condensation of nitrile with NaN3 and NH4Cl or (C2H5)3N.HCl in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) [77], (ii) reaction of nitrile and NaN3 with (C2H5)3N.HCl in toluene [78,79], (iii) condensation of nitriles in water with NaN3 and in the presence of NH4Cl and dodecyltrimethylammonium or hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromides [80], (iv) treatment of nitrile with NaN3 and acetic acid in N-methylpyrrolidin-2-one (NMP) solvent [81], (v) tetrabutylammonium fluoride (TBAF) trihydrate catalyzed reaction of trimethylsilyl azide (TMSN3) and nitrile [82], (vi) microwave assisted treatment of NaN3 with nitrile and ZnCl2 in H2O [83], (vii) condensation of amide, NaN3 and tetrachlorosilane in MeCN [84], (viii) using zinc bromide for condensation of NaN3 and nitrile in water under reflux situation [85,86], (ix) condensation of nitrile and NaN3 in DMF using heterogeneous catalysts such as Pt NPs decorated on reduced graphene oxide (Pt NPs@rGO), activated carbon (Pt NPs@AC), Cu-MCM-41, MZNSS (mesoporous ZnS nanospheres), CoY Zeolite, K10-M (M = Fe, Zn, Cu, Ni), Amberlyst-15, Cu(II) supported on aminated epichlorohydrin activated silica (CAES) (Fig. 6 ), monodisperse Pd/Co nanoparticles decorated multi-walled carbon nanotubes (Mw-Pd/Co@CNT NPs), Ln(OTf)3-SiO2, SnCl2-nano-SiO2 etc. (Scheme 1) [33,87-98]. 2.2 1-Substituted 1H-1,2,3,4-tetrazoles Two key paths have been reported for the synthesis of this group of tetrazoles by means of (a) the reaction of orthocarboxylic acid ester or orthoformate with amines using an azide salt, and (b) cycloaddition of isocyanide and hydrazoic acid. Different catalytic routes have been established for the synthesis of this class of tetrazoles including copper coordinated-poly(α-amino acid) immobilized on magnetite graphene oxide, [EtNH3][NO3] and [PMIM(SO3H)][OTf], 2-aminoethanesulfonic acid supported on epichlorohydrin functionalized Fe3O4@WO3, chitosan supported magnetic ionic liquid NPs, P2O5-SiO2, RuO2/MMT, tributylmethylammonium chloride, glacial acetic acid, 1-n-butylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, Cu NPs/bentonite, silver oxide, immobilized AlCl3 on Al2O3, SiO2-H3BO3, indium triflate, ytterbium triflate hydrate, trifluoromethanesulfonimide, and nano CoFe2O4 (Scheme 2) [75,99-114]. In addition, these compounds can be prepared from the reaction of isocyanides with azide anions in the presence of HCl (Scheme 3) [115]. 2.3 Aminotetrazoles Widespread applications of aminotetrazoles have caused researchers to investigate routes for their synthesis. Some traditional ways to prepare this kind of tetrazoles are (a) the reaction between NaN3 with imidoyl chlorides, aminoiminomethanesulfonic acids, cyanamides, carbodiimides, and thioureas, (b) reaction of tetrazoles with a leaving group in 5-position, (c) condensation of aminoguanidine with sodium nitrite, (d) conversion of 1-aryltetrazoles via a single step consecutive ring opening process with organolithium reagents and NaN3 at -70°C, (e) the reaction between cyanamides with HN3, (f) tetrazoles isomerization (Scheme 4) [116-122]. Newer routes for the preparation of aminotetrazoles include the use of heterogeneous catalysts rather than homogenous ones, which afford an easier work-up procedure involving easy separation of the catalyst from the reaction media [21,123]. 2.4 Arylaminotetrazole The addition of the azide ion to arylcyanamides is the important common route for the preparation of arylaminotetrazole. Arylaminotetrazoles can be observed in two isomeric forms. Scheme 5 shows the two isomeric forms of this category of tetrazoles and different methods for their synthesis. Traditionally, hydrazoic acid has been used as the source of N3 −. Nowadays, NaN3 salt is becoming more popular owing to its safety [90,116,124-132]. The condensation of NaN3 with arylcyanamides in DMF or water as the solvent using glacial acetic acid, ZnCl2, AlCl3, etc. as homogeneous catalysts is a widely used method for arylaminotetrazole preparation [126,127,131,132]. This procedure can also be carried out under solvent-free conditions using Al(HSO4)3, followed by the addition of water in the second step [133]. Recently, the preparation and application of heterogeneous catalysts have attracted much attention [21,119,120,121,123,126]. 2.5 Aryloxytetrazoles A reported process for the formation of various derivatives of 5-aryloxytetrazole involves the reaction of NaN3 and aryl cyanates with consequent acidification (Scheme 6) [134]. Furthermore, an effective and simple route has been reported for the synthesis of 5-aryloxytetrazoles in high purity and yields using aryl cyanates using catalysts such as silica sulfuric acid, Al2O3-SO3H, Mg(HSO4)2, CoFe2O4 NPs, etc. (Scheme 7) [135-137]. 2.6 Thiotetrazoles Sulfur is one of the basic components of batteries and black gunpowder and is used in the manufacture of chemicals (fungicides) and rubber [138]. Its numerous derivatives are used in medicine, agriculture, and industry. 5-Sulfenyl tetrazoles are a distinct group of tetrazoles present in active pharmaceutical ingredients such as latamoxef and cefamandole and some the other bioactive molecules [139]. This tetrazole can be prepared by various methods; namely, (i) using ionic liquids for the reaction between coumarine derivatives, KSCN and NaN3, (ii) condensation of phenacyl bromides, NaN3 and KSCN using ionic liquids, (iii) treatment of naphthylamines with NaN3 by Et3N.HCl in PhMe, (iv) condensation of indoles and pyrroles with NaN3 in 2-propanol/water under ZnBr2 promotion, (v) treatment of benzyl thiocyanate with NaN3 in the presence of ZnCl2 in isopropanol etc. (Scheme 8) [140-143]. 2.7 N‐Benzyl‐N‐aryl‐5‐amino‐1H‐tetrazoles N-Alkyl-N-arylaminotetrazoles and N-acyl-N-arylaminotetrazoles are two types of aminotetrazole derivatives. In these compounds, the nitrogen atom of the amino group was substituted with the alkyl and carbonyl groups. One of the most important these compounds is N‐benzyl‐N‐aryl‐5‐amino‐1H‐tetrazoles. A route to synthesize these compounds is the reaction of N‐benzyl‐N‐arylcyanamides with NaN3 using reduced GO (rGO) immobilized with Cu-Ni NPs (Scheme 9) [144]. The catalyst was prepared using extract of C. a. var. aronia L. leaf via loading of Ni NPs, Cu NPs on the rGO surface. There is also another route for the synthesis of the same tetrazoles via the condensation of 1-aryl-5-methyl-1H-tetrazoles with 1,2-dehydrobenzene (Scheme 10) [145]. 2.8 N-Sulfonyl-N-aryl-5-amino-1H-tetrazoles If the N atom of the arylaminotetrazoles was replaced with sulfonyl groups, the N-sulfonyl-arylaminotetrazoles are created. A reported method for the synthesis of these tetrazoles is the condensation of NaN3 with tertiary cyanamide using Cu NPs@Fe3O4-chitosan (Cu-MCS) as a recyclable catalyst in water medium (Scheme 11) [123]. The catalyst was prepared by loading Cu NPs on MCS using plant extract. 2.9 Tetrazoles synthesized via isocyanide-based reactions Among multicomponent reactions for the synthesis of tetrazoles [146], isocyanide-based reactions are one of significant methods for the synthesis of these compounds. These reactions are divided into three groups including the following cases: 2.9.1 Two-components reactions The one of the main routes for the synthesis of 1-substituted tetrazoles is reaction between HN3 and isocyanides [147,148]. Also, the cycloaddition of isocyanides with TMSN3 under catalyst- and solvent-free or using various catalysts such as CeCl3, YbCl3, HCl and ZnCl2 and solvents for example H2O, MeOH and THF was used for the synthesis of many tetrazoles [115,149]. For the synthesis of optically pure tetrazoles, a type of optically active nitriles (N-Fmoc-protected isonitriles) reacted with TMSN3 in the presence of catalyst (ZnBr2) in dry methanol for 6 h [150]. Scheme 12 shows these methods used to synthesize tetrazoles. 2.9.2 Passerini-azide reactions In the first time, Passerini and Ragni reported Passerini-azide reactions for production of tetrazoles in 1931. In this reaction, the reaction between HN3, isocyanide and reactive carbonyl compounds gave the tetrazoles in good yields. By using different carbonyl compounds, HN3 or TMSN3 as azide source and also isocyanide derivatives under various conditions, types of tetrazoles can be easily prepared (Scheme 13) [151-154]. 2.9.3 Ugi-azide reactions The first example of an Ugi-azide reactions was reported in 1961. This reaction including the condensation of amines with carbonyl compounds which is followed by nucleophilic attack of isocyanide, then reacted by HN3 (or TMSN3). Finally, an intramolecular cyclization happens to achieve derivatives of tetrazole. The several of examples reported to synthesize tetrazole by Ugi-azide reactions is shown in Scheme 14 [155-161]. 3 Characterization of tetrazoles Monosubstituted tetrazoles (tetrazolic acid) that contain a free N-H bond (Fig. 7 ) are acidic molecules and characterized by 1HNMR technique. It should be stated that these compounds exhibit physical properties similar to carboxylic acids. Tetrazolic acids contain N-H bond have pKa values similar to corresponding carboxylic acids and exhibit a peak at low fields in the 1HNMR spectra (Fig. 8 a) [144,162-168]. This proton is very acidic owing to the moiety ability to stabilize negative charge by π-electron delocalization and characterized by high aromaticity. The both compounds exhibit a planar structure and ionized at physiological pH = 7.4. It should be stated that tetrazole anion is almost 10 times more lipophilic than carboxylates anion, which is a significant aspect in drug design [169]. A comprehensive search of the literature exhibits that the 13C NMR spectra of the tetrazoles showed one signal at 145-160 ppm for the carbon of tetrazole (Fig. 8b) [144,170]. In general, all of tetrazoles are highly soluble in solvents such as DMSO, DMF and ethyl acetate and crystallized from aqueous alcoholic solution. However, many tetrazoles are soluble in water [162]. In most cases, the base is need for the synthesis of tetrazole-based catalysts. In the presence of base, the corresponding tetrazolate anionic species can be easily produced. These species have higher capacity than the protic species for hydrogen bonding and also are more reactive than the corresponding neutral species toward alkylating agents and also a variety of electrophiles [162,171]. 4 Environmental applications of tetrazole-based (nano)catalysts There are several main reasons for using tetrazoles in the preparation of catalyst including: Ø High and chemical stability Ø Strong acidic nature Ø High nucleophilic activity Ø Low toxicity Ø Unique biological activities Ø Non-corrosive properties, in most cases, tetrazoles were used as inhibitor in corrosion science [172,173] Ø Ease of handling and preparation of start materials for the synthesis of tetrazoles Ø Simple and economic preparation and easy work-up procedure. There are several methods for the synthesis of tetrazoles in water as green solvent Ø Easy purification and characterization Ø Wide scope of tetrazoles (parent, monosubstituted and disubstituted tetrazoles) Ø Formation a great variety of stable metal-tetrazole complexes due to their wide scope and various coordination modes. Tetrazoles or tetrazolates have several coordination modes (I-VII) (Fig. 9 ) and act as multidentate ligands in coordination chemistry (Fig. 10 ) or versatile building blocks in supramolecular assemblies [174-186] Ø Wide and excellent application of tetrazoles in the preparation of metal-organic framework (MOF) architectures Ø Simple immobilization of tetrazoles onto various supports Ø High ability of tetrazoles as stabilizer agents and precursors for the synthesis of nanomaterials (Fig. 11 ) [187-196] Ø Easy synthesis of novel tetrazole-based ionic liquids. It should be stated that there are few examples for these type of ionic liquids which make it a suitable substitution for imidazoles Ø The use of tetrazolium-based ionic liquids as both solvent and ligand [193-196] Tetrazole based (nano)materials explored as heterogeneous catalysts with high catalytic ability for environmental applications in recent years such as degradation of organic dyes and nitroarenes as toxic and hazardous pollutants are summarized in this section. One of the most important water pollutants is nitro compounds. There are several ways to remove these materials from water, the most important and most practical of which is the catalytic reduction of these compounds. For this work, researchers applied different heterogeneous catalysts [197-201]. Different supports can be applied for the preparation of these catalysts which including Fe3O4@SiO2 [202,203], synthetic or natural polymers [204-210], and silica [211,212]. In 2019, Nasrollahzadeh et al. reported the utilization of a facile method to immobilize ((1-phenyl-1H-tetrazole-5-thiol) Pd(II)) complex on Fe3O4@SiO2 to synthesize an efficient and heterogeneous catalyst (Scheme 15) [213]. This novel catalytic system (Fe3O4@SiO2-Tet-thio-Pd(II)) exhibited excellent prowess in the reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) to 4-aminophenol (4-AP) and Cr(VI) to Cr(III) in water. The catalyst could be reused 5 times with high efficiency. In addition to nitro and Cr(VI) compounds, there are other compounds such as nigrosin (NS) and potassium hexacyanoferrate(III) (K3[Fe(CN)6]) that cause water pollution. Sajjadi et al. successfully designated a novel and effective process to prepare magnetic Pd(II) nanocatalyst (Scheme 16) [214]. The as-synthesized highly magnetically active catalyst (Fe3O4@SiO2-Thiotet-Pd(II)) was used in the degradation of pollutants such as NS, 4-NP, K3Fe(CN)6, and Cr(VI) in water. The catalyst showed antibacterial activity towards Escherichia coli. The catalyst can be recycled and reused in 8 cycles by magnetic decantation. In another study in 2019, Nasrollahzadeh et al. successfully reported a novel method to prepare Pd(II)-tetrazole complex decorated on silica covered Fe3O4 NPs (Fe3O4@SiO2-Tet-Pd(II)) (Scheme 17) [215]. They used 5-phenyl-1H-tetrazole as an appropriate ligand and decorated it on the Fe3O4@SiO2 surface. The synthesized nanocomplex was applied in the reduction of Cr(VI) (Scheme 18), 4-NP (Scheme 19) and 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (2,4-DNPH) using NaBH4. The synthesized catalyst can be reused in 5 cycles with high efficiency. With the expansion of the food processing, cosmetic, printing, paper, and ceramics industries, many pollutants such as synthetic pigments and organic dyes have entered the environment. Methylene blue (MB) is one of the most important organic pigments, the removal of which from the environment is of particular importance [216-221]. In 2018, Nasrollahzadeh et al. successfully developed a novel catalyst by decoration of Cu(II)-5-phenyl-1H-tetrazole complex on the surface of Fe3O4@SiO2 NPs (Fe3O4@SiO2-Tet-Cu(II)) (Scheme 20) [222]. The synthesized catalyst was applied in the reduction reaction of 2,4-DNPH to 2,4-diaminophenylhydrazine (2,4-DAPH) (Scheme 21), Nigrosin (NS), MB and 4-NP in water at room temperature by applying NaBH4 as the reductant. Fe3O4@SiO2-Tet-Cu(II) can be reused for 5 runs with high efficiency. Recently coordination polymers (CPs) have attracted the attention of many researchers in various fields such as sensor, catalysis, gas storage, separation, etc. Some of the CPs have low photocatalytic activity. Some researchers displayed that using functionalization of these materials with conducting polymers such as polypyrrole (PPy) and polyaniline (PANI), can be increased their photocatalytic properties [223-227]. In 2018, Wang and co-workers developed the preparation of three types of coordination polymers including tetrazole; [Co(4-bptzp)(1,3-BDC)]n (1), [Zn(4-bptzp)(1,3-BDC)]n (2), and [Cd(4-bptzp)(1,3-BDC)]n (3) (4-bptzp = 1,4-bis(5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolyl)propane, 1,3-H2BDC 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid) using solvothermal conditions [228]. The structural investigation of these complexes showed 1D chain and 2D supramolecular networks. Furthermore, they synthesized polypyrrole (PPy) functionalized complexes 1-3 composites (PPy/1-PPy/3) by the in situ chemical oxidation polymerization in the presence of ammonium persulfate as an initiator. These complexes display low photocatalytic prowess in the degradation of congo red (CR)/rhodamine B (RhB) while the PPy/1 and PPy/2 show high photocatalytic prowess in the elimination of dyes under UV irradiation. Recently polyoxometalates (POMs) attracted much attention of many researchers due to their properties such as acid/base, photochemical, and redox, which applied in various fields such as catalysis, medicine, electrochemistry, and nanotechnology. In addition, these materials have oxygen-rich surfaces, which this feature makes these compounds suitable options for the construction of inorganic-organic hybrid complexes [229-232]. In 2018, Wang et al. synthesized novel metal organic complexes based on polyoxometalate (POM) [233]. ([Co3(Htyptz)2(γ-Mo8O26)(H2O)6]•4H2O and H2[Co3(Htyptz)2(TeMo6O24)(H2O)8]•6H2O) are the first examples of this kind of complexes derived from H2typtz (3-(tetrazol-5-yl)-5-(pyrid-3-yl)-1,2,4-triazolyl) ligand (Fig. 12 ). They show high electrocatalytic activity towards the reduction of nitrite and bromate. 5 Catalytic applications of tetrazole-based (nano)catalysts in organic synthesis 5.1 C-C and C-N coupling reactions In organic chemistry, one of the most important reactions is the C-C coupling reaction which including Sonogashira, Heck, Hiyama, and Suzuki-Miyaura [234-243]. These reactions produced different compounds such as conjugated polymers, heterocycles, natural products, and dendrimers. Among these coupling reactions, the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling is most applicable [244-250]. Researchers for the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction applied heterogeneous catalysts usually. For this work, they used various appropriate supports which most applicable are natural polymers [251]. Lignin is an amorphous polymer that includes three chief monomer blocks viz. sinapyl alcohol, coniferyl, and p-coumaryl and widely applied as efficient support for the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts. An efficient, low cost and eco-friendly route to synthesize Fe3O4-lignosulfonate@5-amino-1H-tetrazole-Pd(II) (FLA-Pd) (Scheme 22) as a novel and reusable catalyst was reported by Nasrollahzadeh and coworkers [252]. The obtained FLA-Pd catalyst was employed in the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction in water (Scheme 22). The FLA-Pd was simply recovered and reused with no observable loss of catalytic activity after seven cycles. In another study, researchers used Sonogashira and Heck coupling reactions. In 2017, Nemati et al. designed an easy route for the efficient synthesis of active, stable and recyclable magnetic catalyst immobilized nano-palladium (Fe3O4@SiO2-T/Pd) through a [2 + 3] cycloaddition method (Scheme 23) [253]. The fabricated catalyst was employed in the Sonogashira and Heck coupling reactions (Scheme 24). Furthermore, the catalyst could be simply removed by a permanent magnet and reused six times with high efficiency. Recently the NHC-Pd complexes with additional ligands have established much consideration and displayed hopeful catalytic performance in different organic reactions [254-258]. In these compounds, there are different types of ligands but researchers investigated that tetrazole ligands are most applicable. In 2016, Yang developed the synthesis of six novel NHC(N-heterocyclic carbene)-Pd(II) complexes based on three types of tetrazoles [259]. For this aim, he used tetrazole as nitrogen donors in the preparation of different NHC-Pd complexes (Scheme 25). The crystal structure of these compounds displayed mononuclear and dinuclear NHC-Pd complexes. The synthesized catalysts could be efficiently used in Hiyama coupling reaction (Scheme 26). The use of copper-based catalysts is one of the great approaches for C-N cross-coupling reactions. This reaction can be synthesized N-arylated nitrogens that play an important role like intermediates in various fields such as pharmaceuticals, energetic, chemical and agrochemicals industries. A novel ligand, tetrazole-1-acetic acid, was applied in the N-arylation of imidazole catalyzed by CuI under slight conditions (Scheme 27) [260]. The advantages of this reaction are excellent yields, low catalyst loading and no need for an inert gas. 5.2 Cyanation of aryl halides Aryl nitrile derivatives attracted much consideration from researchers owing to their properties and probable applications. These compounds can be synthesized using the reaction of aryl halides with cyanide sources. For example in 2019, Nasrollahzadeh and colleagues successfully investigated the synthesis of an efficient and new nanocomplex by decoration of Pd(II)‐tetrazole complex on the Fe3O4@SiO2 NPs (Fe3O4@SiO2‐BAT‐Pd(II)) (Scheme 28) [261]. The synthesized nanocomplex was applied in the cyanation of aryl halides including I and Br using potassium hexacyanoferrate(II) as a safe and low cost cyanating agent under ligand‐free conditions. The synthesized nanocatalyst can be removed from the reaction media by an external magnet and reused 6 times with high efficiency. 5.3 Oxidation of organic compounds One of the most applicable reactions is oxidation reactions, which occurs under various reaction conditions such as various oxidants, solvents, catalysts, and temperature [262-269]. In 2018, Ghosh et al. developed a well-organized route for the synthesis of two new types of cobalt(III) tetrazolato complexes using azide and Schiff bases as co-ligands [270]. They prepared two compounds by the in situ generation of tetrazole from the reaction of 2-cyanopyridine and NaN3 (Scheme 29) using Schiff bases and Co(NO3)2.6H2O under atmospheric conditions (Scheme 30). They applied these complexes as efficient catalysts in the oxidation of 3,5-di-tert-butylcatechol (3,5-DTBC) and o-aminophenol to the corresponding compounds with acetonitrile-methanol mixture (2:1) as the solvent under aerobic condition. Water photocatalytic oxidation can be produced H2. Among various photocatalysts, which are applied for this purpose, the copper-based complexes have attracted much attention from researchers. In 2018, Jiang and colleagues developed the synthesis of [Cu(tza)2]n ((Htza, tetrazole-1-acetic acid) Cu tetrazolate coordination polymer [97]. The synthesized compound was employed as the catalyst in photocatalytic water oxidation reaction (Scheme 31). The experimental result showed that the catalyst has high catalytic prowess compared with other copper-based photocatalysts for water oxidation. Another effort was taken by Frija et al. regarding the organization of an organocatalyst, 3-((2-methyl-2H-tetrazol-5-yl)amino)benzisothiazole 1,1-dioxide (5) by two heterocyclic parts viz. tetrazole and benzisothiazole (saccharin) (Scheme 32) [271]. They studied the catalytic activity of tetrazole-amino-saccharin (5) to oxidize benzyl alcohols within 30 min by tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant under solvent-free and microwave conditions (Scheme 33). In 2016, Frija et al. successfully developed the synthesis of new cobalt(II) and copper(II) tetrazole-saccharinate complexes (Scheme 34) [272]. They used 2-methyltetrazole-saccharinate as a bidentate ligand. The prepared complexes were utilized in the solvent-free oxidation of secondary alcohols using TBHP (Scheme 35). Recently the binding of DNA and tetrazole metal complexes has appealed much consideration owing to their site particular binding features and varied range of applications. Mukhopadhyay et al. developed a route to obtain two Cu(II) complexes ([Cu{(5-pyrazinyl)tetrazolate}2(1,10-phenanthroline)] 1 and [Cu{(5-pyrazinyl)tetrazolate}(1,10-phenanthroline)2](NO3)0.5(N3)0.5 2) by [2 + 3] cycloaddition of pyrazinecarbonitrile and Cu bound azide (Scheme 36) [273]. 1 and 2 octahedral complexes can interact with DNA and serum albumin protein, complex 2 being a stronger binder. In addition, complex 2 was used as an effective catecholase in the oxidation of 3,5-di-tertbutylcatechol (3,5-DTBC) (Scheme 37). In 2014, Secci and his research group studied the oxidation of organosulphides catalyzed by hydrogen bonding donors derived from aminotetrazole (Scheme 38) [274]. Sulphoxides were obtained in excellent selectivity and yields in H2O using H2O2 as a chemoselective, green, versatile, and new method. Aminotetrazole derivatives can be separated and reused for several runs with no expensive purification procedures. In recent years, researchers investigated the synthesis of different types of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and applied them in various reactions [275-280]. In 2014, Nasani and colleagues reported two types of MOFs {[Cu3(µ3-4-ptz)4(µ2-N3)2(DMF)2](DMF)2}n (1) and {[Cu(4-ptz)2(H2O)2]}n (2) {4-ptz = 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolate} via 3D and 2D structural networks, respectively [281]. They fabricated the catalysts by the cycloaddition of 4-cyanopyridine and azide by CuCl2 (Scheme 39). The synthesized catalysts displayed high catalytic prowess in the oxidation of secondary alcohols with high yield (> 99%) (Scheme 40). Secci and co-workers reported the chemoselective oxidation of organosulphides catalyzed by aminotetrazole derivatives as hydrogen bonding donors (Fig. 13 ) in various solvents by TBHP in high yields (Scheme 41 ) [282]. 1H-NMR and DFT analysis were used to characterize tetrazole amide-TBHP complexes in the oxidation of sulphides. The derivatives from tetrazole amide can be simply recycled through easy filtration and recycled several times. 5.4 Synthesis of organic compounds In 2018, Nasrollahzadeh et al. successfully prepared a new magnetic catalyst using Cu(II)-aminotetrazole complex decorated on silica covered Fe3O4 NPs (Fe3O4@SiO2-aminotet-Cu(II)) (Scheme 42 ) [21]. The synthesized magnetic catalyst can be applied in the effective organization of a diversity of arylaminotetrazoles, with high yields (Scheme 43 ) and reused for 6 cycles with high efficiency. A special combination of liquids that contain only ions is called ionic liquid. These materials have various properties such as low vapor pressure, high thermal stability, and exceptional solvation and can be recycled. However, the use of these compounds is limited due to their toxicity. Newly, solid acid catalysts have concerned much devotion in the organic reactions. In addition, there are many Brønsted acids, which are applied as green and free-of-metal catalysts [283-287]. In 2018, Nasrollahzadeh et al. established an efficient, novel method to prepare heterogeneous Brønsted acidic ionic liquid [288]. They reported decorating tetrazole-bonded sulfonic acid on the surface of Fe3O4@SiO2 ([FSTet-SO3H]Cl) (Scheme 44 ). The synthesized ionic liquid ([FSTet-SO3H]Cl) was applied in the preparation of 1-carbamoyl-1-phenylureas in water at short reaction times (Scheme 45 ). The synthesized catalyst can be separated by an external magnet and reused for several cycles. In 2017, Dang et al. reported the preparation of novel 3D copper-phosphonate network (Cu7(H1L)2(TPT)3(H2O)6) by a hydrothermal process using a nitrogen containing ancillary ligand (TPT: [5-(4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)phenyl)-1H-tetrazole]) and a rigid tetrahedral linker of tetraphenylsilane tetrakis-4-phosphonic acid (H8L). The synthesized compound was employed as an active catalyst in the CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides (Scheme 46 ) [289]. Furthermore, it exhibits excellent catalytic performance in the ring opening reaction of styrene oxide with MeOH (Scheme 47 ). The catalyst can be readily recycled 3 times with high efficiency. In 2018, Habibi and Heydari developed an efficient method for synthesis of novel tetrazole functionalized Pd NPs decorated polymer (BBC-Polym@PTT@Pd) by functionalization of 4-(benzyloxy)benzyl chloride polymer bound (BBC-Polym) with 1-phenyl-1H-tetrazole-5-thiol (PTT), followed by the complexation with PdCl2 (Scheme 48 ) [290]. The synthesized heterogeneous catalyst was applied for the alkylation of cyanamides in CH3CN (Scheme 49 ). The catalyst was reused for 5 times with high efficiency. In 2018, Nakashima and Yamamoto reported the preparation of an effective and simple organocatalyst using a packed bed column with proline tetrazole [291]. The synthesized organocatalyst can be applied in the continuous flow-column system with excellent yield for different conversions such as Mannich, o-nitroso aldol and aldol reactions (Scheme 50 ). The synthesized organocatalyst can be used 10 times with high efficiency. In 2017, Nakashima and Yamamoto used proline tetrazole in an asymmetric aldol reaction of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde and acetone (Scheme 51 ) [292]. The proline tetrazole was proved to be much more active than L-proline. 3 mol % of additional water improved the efficacy of aldol products in excellent yield and increased the enantioselectivity up to 0.1 mol-scale production (84% ee, up to 99% isolated yield). In 2014, Maji and Yamamoto used proline-tetrazole as a catalyst to prepare β-amino alcohols (Scheme 52 ) [293]. Proline-tetrazole catalyzed N-nitroso aldol reaction of the aldehydes. This method presented high enantioselectivity. In this research, the main key to success was the use of catechol as a Brønsted acid and MnO2 as an oxidant. Infinite coordination polymer (ICP) particles (micro and nano-scale) are types of organic-inorganic materials including organic multidentate linkers and metal cations that newly are attractive research fields in both material and chemistry sciences owing to their promising applications. In 2017, Morsali and his research group reported a synthesis route for the synthesis of a tetrazole based infinite coordination polymer (ICP) using Zn2+ metal node (Zn(btb) ICP) (btb = 1,3-bis(tetrazol-5-ylmethyl)-benzene) under ultrasonic irradiation (Scheme 53 ) [294]. Increasing the concentrations of starting materials and ultrasonic irradiation power reduced the size of the product. Zn(btb) ICP was successfully applied in the Michael addition reactions of 1-methylpyrrole to β-nitrostyrene and α,β-unsaturated ketones as a useful Lewis acid catalyst (Scheme 54 ). One of the most potent devices for producing heterocyclic systems is the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reactions. The use of this reaction in chitosan chemistry was synthesized novel chitosan derivatives with exceptional properties such as drug delivery systems, enhanced mechanical properties antibacterial and fungicidal polymers. In 2019, Kritchenkov and co-workers successfully developed a method for synthesis of tetrazole derivatives of chitosan (Scheme 55 ) [295]. Ionic gelation of these compounds with sodium tripolyphosphate lead to the preparation of NPs with 100-800 nm diameter. The synthesized tetrazole derivatives of chitosan and their NPs can be applied as effective catalysts for aldol reaction of p-chlorobenzaldehyde and acetone (Scheme 56 ). The experimental results displayed which the tetrazole derivatives of chitosan have higher catalytic performance than corresponding NPs. However, antibacterial activity of tetrazole-chitosan-based NPs is better than corresponding tetrazole-chitosan polymers. In 2016, Huang et al. successfully demonstrated two types of coordination polymers (CPs) [Zn(pytz)-H2O]n (1; H2pytz = 2,6-bis(tetrazole)pyridine) and [Zn2(pytz)24H2O] (2), which varied in particle sizes and morphologies and were prepared under solvothermal conditions using diverse surfactants such as polyethylene glycol (PEG) 2000 and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as templates, which function as structure directing and capping agents, respectively [296]. The synthesized nanocrystalline 1 and 2 were applied as catalysts in the transformation of aromatic dinitriles to the corresponding oxazolines (Scheme 57 ). The experimental results displayed that 1 and 2 formed bis-oxazolines as the only product and mono-oxazolines as the main product, respectively. The synthesized catalysts could also be reused. The preparation of Cu(4-nptz), as a tetrazolate based coordination complex and analysis of its structure was reported by Ma et al [297]. The complex was fabricated from the hydrothermal reaction of 5-(4-nitrophenyl)-2H-tetrazole [H(4-nptz)] and CuCl. The complex exhibits the first 3D framework fabricated via 4-nptz ligand, it is insoluble in any solvent and stable at ambient temperature. The catalytic system was used in 4-nitrophenyl acetate hydrolysis, reduced the reaction time and increased the yield (Scheme 58 ). Lee et al. synthesized tetrazole based titanium complexes including ([(η5-C5H5)Ti L Cl2] (1), [Ti L Cl3(THF)] (2) and [Ti L 2Cl2] (3) 5-(2-hydroxyphenyl)tetrazole ( LH )) in which L performed as a bidentate ligand and hydrogen bonding between the hydrogen of the tetrazolyl unit and oxygen of the tetrahydrofuran (Scheme 59 ) [298]. They studied the catalytic behavior of these complexes in the CO2 cycloaddition to propylene oxide (Scheme 60 ). Complex 3 exhibited the best activity. Table 1 summarizes some other reactions, which have employed tetrazole and its derivatives as catalyst. 6 High energy tetrazole-based (nano)materials In recent years, the preparation of high energy density materials (HEDMs) has become a hot topic for researchers [328-337]. HEDMs are useful in military and civilian applications as important functional compounds [338-347]. They can be used to develop weapons, mining, civilian space technologies, and explosion welding [348-358]. The explosive materials should satisfy a series of requirements including: Ø C/H/N ratio should be characterized by high N content and low H and C contents Ø Safety and non-hazardous for the environment Ø They should be a chemical compound (not a mixture) with an adequate quantity of oxidizer and propellant Ø Low solubility in water, material compatibility and stability Ø High density with high detonation parameters Ø High standard enthalpy of formation-reflected as heat amount released during explosives decomposition Ø Relatively high insensitivity to heat, electrostatic discharge and mechanical stimuli Among HEDMs, metal-based explosives such as lead azide Pb(N3)2 have been prepared as primary explosives. These materials show high sensitivity toward friction, impact, heat, shock, and electrostatic discharge and can generate an extremely rapid deflagration-to-detonation transition that can be applied to initiate larger masses of secondary explosives such as HMX (1,3,5,7-tetranitro-1,3,5,7-tetraazacyclooctane), RDX (1,3,5-trinitro-1,3,5-triazacyclohexane), and others [359-363]. However, lead azide is very toxic to human beings and environment. In addition, the fabrication of traditional energetic materials, including hexogen (RDX), octogen (HMX), trinitrotoluene (TNT) and pentaerythritol tetranitrate (PETN) is hard and they are not environmentally compatible [364-373]. Recently, efforts towards the preparation of new explosive materials such as tetrazoles with higher environmental compatibility and lower toxicity have increased [374-383]. Researchers are trying to create optimal balance between high thermal stability, excellent ignition performance and moderate sensitivity to several mechanical stimuli [384-389]. Tetrazole-based salts are a significant core of energetic materials due to unique properties [333,390-393] such as: ü Owing to the ring strain and high nitrogen content, tetrazoles may be of high density, have high heats of formation, and release considerable gases and energy upon explosion or decomposition; ü Due to aromaticity, the tetrazole ring is stable in the presence of alkalis, acids and during long times of heating and boiling; ü The replacement of ring substituents in tetrazoles with functional groups can be easily modified their explosive and physical properties; ü These salts are safety for the environment, since their products upon decomposition consist of dinitrogen Bistetrazoles are of exceptional notice since of their potential to perform as chelating ligands creating five- or six-membered rings with the coordination site for metals. Recently researchers investigated the energetic application of 1,5′-isomer due to its high nitrogen amount. In 2013, Klapötke and co-workers synthesized 5-(tetrazol-1-yl)-2H-tetrazole or 1,5′-bistetrazole by the cyclization of 5-amino-1H-tetrazole, triethyl orthoformate, and NaN3 in glacial acetic acid [394]. Starting the same route from 5-amino-2-methyl-tetrazole gives 2-methyl-5-(tetrazol-1-yl)tetrazole (Scheme 61 ). Different salts of these tetrazole derivatives were prepared (Scheme 62 ) and characterized using IR, Raman, mass spectrometry, NMR spectroscopy, DSC and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, Bundesamt für Materialforschung (BAM) methods were applied to determine the sensitivity of these compounds to physical stimuli (friction, impact, electrostatic). One of the most applicable materials in energetic applications is 1-nitraminotetrazoles which are used as heavy metal-free primary explosives and other energetic parts. For the first time, in 2016, Klapötke et al. prepared neutral 1,1′-dinitramino-5,5′-bitetrazole (1) and 1,1′-dinitramino-5,5′-azobitetrazole (2) compounds and investigated their salts (3-7) (Scheme 63 ) [395]. The neural compounds were found to be very explosive and sensitive to friction, impact, and electrostatic discharge. The methoxycarbonyl and its derivatives are significant types of organic compounds, which can be applied as intermediates in various applications such as organic synthesis, pesticides, and medicines. In addition, these materials have high oxygen content and could chip in the good oxygen balance (OB) that is an important display for appraising the energy of an explosive. In 2019, He and co-workers synthesized dimethoxycarbonyl diaminobistetrazole (1) and its sodium salt (2) as novel oxygen containing compounds via a facile route (Scheme 64 ) [396]. The formation heats, sensitivity, density, thermal stability and the energetic properties from EXPLO5 code were examined and it was found that these compounds possessed high positive heats of formation and detonation heats. In 2014, Klapötke and co-workers synthesized 5-(5-azido-1H-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl)tetrazole (AzTT) and its metal and N-rich salts including copper(I), copper(II), silver, potassium, cesium, ammonium and guanidinium salts (Schemes 65 and 66 ) [397]. The determinations reveal that most of the metal salts are highly sensitive while the nitrogen rich salts are insensitive. The metal salts were also shown to be capable of being primary explosives. In particular, the dihydroxylammonium 5,5′-bistetrazole-1,1′-diolate (TKX-50) materials were applied as promising high energetic compounds. In 2019, Lee and Kwon successfully developed an efficient method for the synthesis of dihydroxylammonium 5,5′-bistetrazole-1,1′-diolate (TKX-50) [398]. Since TKX-50 production involves the production of a sensitive intermediate, they synthesized TKX-50 using ditetrahydropyranyl diazidoglyoxime (THP-DAG) rather than diazidoglyoxime (DAG) as an insensible intermediate (Scheme 67 ). The synthesized TKX-50 was applied as an energetic material. In 2019, Li et al. reported an effective and simple self-assembly synthetic procedure for the synthesis of bimetallic energetic coordination polymers based on new 1,5-di(nitramino)tetrazole (DNAT), MK2(DNAT)2•4H2O [M = Fe, Cu, Ni, Co, and Zn] [399]. For this aim, they used self-assembly of potassium 1,5-di(nitramino)tetrazolate (Scheme 68 ). The synthesized compounds can be applied as eco-friendly and “green” primary explosives as alternatives for toxic lead(II) azide. Recently many researchers developed nitrogen-rich metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) that have high explosive properties. The energetic MOFs (E-MOFs) can be designed in different structures such as 1D, 2D, and 3D architectures, which depended on, two parameters, include metal ion geometry and binding mode of the bridging energetic ligands. In 2016, Liu and colleagues demonstrated the synthesis of 3D E-MOFs, which have excellent potentials and benefits in the production of energetic materials [400]. They synthesized these compounds using a nitrogen rich E-MOF, Pb(bta) 2H2O [N% = 31.98%, H2bta = N,N-bis(1H-tetrazole-5-yl)-amine] in a one-step hydrothermal process (Scheme 69 ). The experimental results displayed that the nitrogen rich MOF can be applied as an energetic material. In 2016, Nimesh and Ang reported the synthesis and crystal structure of 1-(2H-tetrazol-5-yl)guanidine (1) and its nitrate salt (2) [401]. For this purpose, they used 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of cyanoguanidine (Scheme 70 ). The synthesized compounds displayed excellent thermal stability, comparable densities and high nitrogen content, which make them applicable as green energetic materials such as monopropellant ingredient for cool gas generators. In 2017, Wojewódka and Bełzowski developed the synthesis of novel explosive complexes of the DDT kind and reported their sensitivity to resistance and impact [402]. In this study, they synthesized fourteen novel compounds including nitrate and perchlorate complexes of different transition block metals via 5-(2,4,6-trinitrophenylamino)tetrazole, usually referred to as picrylaminotetrazole (PAT) (Scheme 71 ). In 2019, Zhang and co-workers developed an efficient, green and novel method for the preparation of primary explosives based on coordination chemistry method [403]. They synthesized five new green primary explosives by using energetic coordination polymers (ECPs) based on 1H,1′H-[5,5′-bitetrazole]-1,1′-diol (H2BTO) without any heavy metal cations and organic pollutants (Scheme 72 ). The experimental results showed these compounds are new lead free primary explosives. There are several methods concerning the synthesis of tetrazole-based energetic materials. Some other examples of tetrazole-based explosive materials are presented in Table 2 . 7 Conclusion The synthesis of tetrazoles and tetrazole based (nano)materials is one of the known procedures in material science, nanotechnology and organic chemistry. Recent efforts have identified the potential usefulness of tetrazole for various applications. Tetrazoles useful in catalysis, medicinal chemistry, propellants, antibacterial material, coordination chemistry, organic synthesis, and other fields of application can be synthesized easily. The presence of a ring with four nitrogen atoms makes tetrazole and its derivatives extremely high energetic materials and efficient ligands for the preparation of excellent complexes suitable for catalysis and environmental applications. Despite the developments in the preparation and utilization of homogenous catalysts, they are not very interesting for researchers due to their hard separation from the reaction mixture as an important step in the purification. In this review, we have considered tetrazole based (nano)materials as recyclable heterogeneous catalytic systems, which were found to be efficient in many reactions. From different reactions discussed in this review paper, ranging from oxidation and reduction to cyanation and coupling reactions, it can be seen that the interest towards tetrazole based (nano)materials and their environmental, catalytic and energetic applications are on a rise. We believe that there are good opportunities for industrial scale production and development of applications of tetrazole based (nano)materials in the field of catalysis. However, there are still a number of challenges to be focused on in future such as: v Utilization of tetrazoles as effective ligands to prepare various ionic liquids and high energetic compounds. v Development of new techniques for the synthesis of tetrazole-based (nano)materials. v Development of tetrazole-based (nano)materials with excellent catalytic prowess. v Development and utilization of biowastes as natural supports in the design of tetrazole-based (nano)materials on them. v Utilization of natural supports for the immobilization of various tetrazoles with excellent catalytic activity. v Development of magnetic tetrazole-based (nano)materials or complexes with excellent catalytic prowess. coredata.dc:description: Increasing interest in tetrazoles and tetrazole based materials in the recent century has been followed by enormous research efforts devoted for the synthesis of various kinds of materials based on these five membered heterocyclic compounds, which basically contain four nitrogen atoms. The structure of tetrazoles and their derivatives are crucial in preparing complexes since they can act as ligands to modify the reactivity and selectivity of the metal centers in the catalyst and prepare energetic materials. The wide field of tetrazole applications as efficient, air stable and inexpensive materials has drawn attention to the methods to synthesize various kinds of tetrazoles and their derivatives. This study primarily focuses on the fabrication methods of tetrazoles and preparation of tetrazole based compounds and their utilizations in environmental, catalytic, and energetic applications. The significant applications of tetrazole, as a catalyst, energetic material and efficient ligand in the organic catalysis or formation of various catalysts are described with an emphasis on its performance, reusability and stability and environmental concerns such as treatment of wastewater and water. Finally, a brief summary and an outlook on some of the scientific challenges and opportunities of these materials have also been discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Use of tetrazoles in catalysis and energetic applications: Recent developments
